description: The course provides a unified introduction to momentum, energy (heat), and mass transport processes. The basic mechanisms and the constitutive laws for the various transport processes will be delineated, and the conservation equations will be derived and applied to internal and external flows featuring a few examples from mechanical, chemical, and biological systems. Reactive flows will also be considered.
name: TRANSPORT PROCESSES I

values.comments:
The course introduces momentum, energy (heat), and mass transport processes.
The basic mechanisms and the constitutive laws for the various transport processes are
delineated, and the conservation equations are derived and applied to internal and
external flows featuring a few examples from mechanical, chemical, and biological
systems. Reactive flows are also considered.
Students generally found the course to be “not directly relevant” to their
concentrations in MEAM even though it is a required course, commenting that the
course’s scope was “extremely broad.” Some enjoyed the course very much, indicating
that they learnt “useful theory and math method.”
Students found Professor Ayyaswamy’s notes excellent, praising that “they
contain derivations and detailed explanations which can’t be found in textbooks.”
This course requires students to be prepared with a strong math background,
especially the knowledge of solving ODEs and PDEs. Many students noted that graduate
level engineering math courses and ENM 510 should be the prerequisites.
